meanings.definition: Not taut or held tightly in position
meanings.sent1: The rope was slack, causing the flag to droop.
meanings.sent2: The loose pants felt comfortable with their slack fit.
meanings.sent3: The slack leash allowed the dog to wander off on its own.
meanings.sent4: Her attention to detail was slack, leading to mistakes in her work.
meanings.sent5: The slack grip on the steering wheel made driving feel unsafe.

meanings.definition: A period of time when work is not done or when rules are not followed
meanings.sent1: During the lunch break, there was a slack in productivity.
meanings.sent2: The teacher noticed a slack in attendance after the holiday.
meanings.sent3: The team took advantage of the slack to relax and recharge.
meanings.sent4: The slack in regulations allowed for some creative problem-solving.
meanings.sent5: The slack in the schedule gave them extra time to prepare.

meanings.sent1: He tends to slack off when the boss is not around.
meanings.sent2: Don't slack on your responsibilities; they are important.
meanings.sent3: She decided to slack for a bit before getting back to work.
meanings.sent4: The students chose to slack instead of studying for the test.
meanings.sent5: It's easy to slack when no one is watching, but it's not productive.

meanings.definition: To reduce in activity or speed
meanings.sent1: The company had to slack production due to the supply chain issues.
meanings.sent2: As the day progressed, the wind began to slack.
meanings.sent3: The storm started to slack, giving way to clear skies.
meanings.sent4: The traffic seemed to slack as they approached the outskirts of town.
meanings.sent5: The music gradually began to slack, signaling the end of the performance.
